Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common.check

Class CommonChecks

java.lang.Object
nl.naturalis.common.check.CommonChecks
public final class CommonChecks extends Object
Defines various common tests for arguments. The tests have short, informative error messages associated with them so you don't have to invent them yourself. Unless specified otherwise, they only test what they advertise to be testing. They will not do a preliminary null check! If the argument might be null, always precede them with the notNull() check. Otherwise, a raw, unprocessed NullPointerException will be thrown from the test itself, rather than the application code. 

 Check.notNull(file, "file").is(readable());
 // Or:
 Check.that(file, "file").is(notNull()).is(readable());

The CommonChecks also contains a few static exception factories that you can use in combination with Check.on(...): 


 Check.on(illegalState(), file, "file").is(notNull()).is(readable());

    • NULL

      public static <T> Predicate<T> NULL()
      Verifies that the argument is null. Equivalent to Objects::isNull.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the argument
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • notNull

      public static <T> Predicate<T> notNull()
      Verifies that the argument is not null. Equivalent to Objects::nonNull.
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the argument
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • yes

      public static Predicate<Boolean> yes()
      Verifies that the argument is true. If the argument is a Boolean rather than a boolean and the argument might be null, use nullOr(). 
      
 Check.that(list.isEmpty()).is(yes());
 Check.that(list).has(List::isEmpty, yes());
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • no

      public static Predicate<Boolean> no()
      Verifies that the argument is false. If the argument is a Boolean rather than a boolean and the argument might be null, use nullOr().
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • empty

      public static <T> Predicate<T> empty()
      Verifies that the argument is empty. See ObjectMethods::isEmpty for what counts as an empty object.

      This check performs an implicit null check, so can be safely executed without (or instead of) executing the notNull() check first.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the argument
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • deepNotNull

      public static <T> Predicate<T> deepNotNull()
      Verifies that the argument is not null and, if it is an array, Map or Collection, that it does not contain any null values. This check still allows the array, map or collection to be empty (zero-sized). Use deepNotEmpty() if you want to disallow this, too.

      This check performs an implicit null check, so can be safely executed without (or instead of) executing the notNull() check first.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the argument
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above
      See Also:
      • ObjectMethods.isDeepNotNull(Object)

    • deepNotEmpty

      public static <T> Predicate<T> deepNotEmpty()
      Verifies that the argument is not null, not empty, and, if it is an array, Map or Collection, that it does not contain any null or empty values. Equivalent to ObjectMethods::isDeepNotEmpty.

      This check performs an implicit null check, so can be safely executed without (or instead of) executing the notNull() check first.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the argument
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above
      See Also:
      • ObjectMethods.isDeepNotEmpty(Object)

    • blank

      public static Predicate<String> blank()
      Verifies that a String argument is null or contains whitespace only. Probably more useful when called from an isNot method.

      This check performs an implicit null check, so can be safely executed without (or instead of) executing the notNull() check first.

      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

      public static <X extends Comparable<X>> Relation<X,X> GT()

      X - The type of the values being compared

      A function implementing the test described above

    • supersetOf

      public static <E, C0 extends Collection<? super E>, C1 extends Collection<E>> Relation<C0,C1> supersetOf()
      Verifies that a Collection argument contains all the elements of the specified collection. Equivalent to Collection::containsAll. Note that neither collection needs to be a Set: 
      
 Check.that(List.of(1,2,3)).is(supersetOf(), Set.of(1,2); // valid and true
 Check.that(List.of(1,2)).is(supersetOf(), Set.of(1,2,3); // valid but false
      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of the elements in the Collection
      C0 - The type of the argument (the subject of the Relation)
      C1 - The type of the object of the Relation
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • subsetOf

      public static <E, C0 extends Collection<E>, C1 extends Collection<? super E>> Relation<C0,C1> subsetOf()
      Verifies that a Collection argument is a subset or sublist of another Collection. Note that neither collection needs to be a Set: 
      
 Check.that(List.of(1,2,3)).is(subsetOf(), Set.of(1,2); // valid but false
 Check.that(List.of(1,2)).is(subsetOf(), Set.of(1,2,3); // valid and true
      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of the elements in the Collection
      C0 - The type of the argument (the subject of the Relation)
      C1 - The type of the object of the Relation
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

      public static Relation<String,CharSequence> hasSubstring()

      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

      A function implementing the test described above

    • strlenEQ

      public static ObjIntRelation<String> strlenEQ()
      Verifies that the length of a String argument has the specified value. Although you can use this check with the is() and isNot() method, it is specifically meant to be used with the has() and notHas() methods as there is no API for validating properties of properties: 
      
 // Validate the length of a string argument (not preferred):
 Check.that("FOO").is(strlenEQ(), 3);

 // Validate the length of a string argument (preferred):
 Check.that("FOO").has(strlen(), eq(), 3);

 // Validate the length property of the lastName property of the employee argument:
 Check.that(employee).has(Employee::getLastName, strlenEQ(), 3);
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • strlenGT

      public static ObjIntRelation<String> strlenGT()
      Verifies that the length of a String argument is greater than the specified value. Although you can use this check with the is() and isNot() method, it is specifically meant to be used with the has() and notHas() methods as there is no API for validating properties of properties. 
      
 // Validate the length property of a string argument (not preferred):
 Check.that("FOO").is(strlenGT(), 2);

 // Validate the length property of a string argument (preferred):
 Check.that("FOO").has(strlen(), gt(), 2);

 // Validate the length property of the lastName property of the employee argument:
 Check.that(employee).has(Employee::getLastName, strlenGT(), 2);
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • strlenGTE

      public static ObjIntRelation<String> strlenGTE()
      Verifies that the length of a String argument is greater than or equal to the specified value. Although you can use this check with the is() and isNot() method, it is specifically meant to be used with the has() and notHas() methods as there is no API for validating properties of properties.
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above
      See Also:
      • strlenGT()

    • strlenLT

      public static ObjIntRelation<String> strlenLT()
      Verifies that the length of a String argument is less than the specified value. Although you can use this check with the is() and isNot() method, it is specifically meant to be used with the has() and notHas() methods as there is no API for validating properties of properties.
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above
      See Also:
      • strlenGT()

    • strlenLTE

      public static ObjIntRelation<String> strlenLTE()
      Verifies that the length of a String argument is less than or equal to the specified value. Although you can use this check with the is() and isNot() method, it is specifically meant to be used with the has() and notHas() methods as there is no API for validating properties of properties.
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above
      See Also:
      • strlenGT()

    • sizeEQ

      public static <E, C extends Collection<E>> ObjIntRelation<C> sizeEQ()
      Verifies that the size of a Collection argument has the specified value. Although you can use this check with the is() and isNot() method, it is specifically meant to be used with the has() and notHas() methods as there is no API for validating properties of properties: 
      
 // Validate the size property of a collection argument (not preferred):
 Check.that(List.of("A", "B", "C")).is(sizeEQ(), 3);

 // Validate the size property of a collection argument (preferred):
 Check.that(List.of("A", "B", "C")).has(size(), eq(), 3);

 // Validate the size property of the employees property of the company argument:
 Check.that(company).has(Company::getEmployees, sizeEQ(), 3);
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • sizeGT

      public static <E, C extends Collection<E>> ObjIntRelation<C> sizeGT()
      Verifies that the size of a Collection argument is greater than the specified value. Although you can use this check with the is() and isNot() method, it is specifically meant to be used with the has() and notHas() methods as there is no API for validating properties of properties: 
      
 // Validate the size property of a collection argument (not preferred):
 Check.that(List.of("A", "B", "C")).is(sizeGT(), 2);

 // Validate the size property of a collection argument (preferred):

 // Validate the size property of the employees property of the company argument:

      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • lenEQ

      public static <T> ObjIntRelation<T> lenEQ()
      Verifies that the size of an array argument is equal to the specified value. No preliminary check is done to determine if the argument actually is an array. Execute the array() check first if there is any doubt about this. Although you can use this check with the is() and isNot() method, it is specifically meant to be used with the has() and notHas() methods as there is no API for validating properties of properties: 
      
 // Validate the length of an array argument (not preferred):
 Check.that(new int[10]).is(lenEQ(), 10);

 // Validate the length of an array argument (preferred):
 Check.that(new int[10]).has(length(), eq(), 10);


 // Validate the length property of the employees array of the company argument:
 Check.that(company).has(Company::getEmployees, lenEQ(), 25);
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • lenGT

      public static <T> ObjIntRelation<T> lenGT()
      Verifies that the size of an array argument is greater than the specified value. No preliminary check is done to determine if the argument actually is an array. Execute the array() check first if there is any doubt about this. Although you can use this check with the is() and isNot() method, it is specifically meant to be used with the has() and notHas() methods as there is no API for validating properties of properties.
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • lenGTE

      public static <T> ObjIntRelation<T> lenGTE()
      Verifies that the size of an array argument is greater than or equal to the specified value. No preliminary check is done to determine if the argument actually is an array. Execute the array() check first if there is any doubt about this. Although you can use this check with the is() and isNot() method, it is specifically meant to be used with the has() and notHas() methods as there is no API for validating properties of properties.
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • lenLT

      public static <T> ObjIntRelation<T> lenLT()

      A function implementing the test described above

      public static <T> ObjIntRelation<T> lenLTE()

Execute the array() check first if there is any doubt about this.       Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • indexOf

      public static <T> IntObjRelation<T> indexOf()
      Verifies that the argument can be used as index into the specified array or array-like object. The object of this relation must be one of the following:
      • an array
      • an instance of List
      • an instance of String
      An InvalidCheckException is thrown if the argument has any other type. 
      
 Check.that(4).is(indexOf(), "Hello world!"); // true
 Check.that(5).is(indexOf(), new File[5]); // false
 Check.that(-1).is(indexOf(), List.of("foo", "bar")); // false
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the array
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • indexInclusiveOf

      public static <T> IntObjRelation<T> indexInclusiveOf()
      Verifies that the argument can be used as a "from" or "to" index in operations like substring and subList. In other words, that the argument is greater than, or equal to zero, and less than or equal to the length or the specified array or array-like object. The object of this relation must be one of the following:
      • an array
      • an instance of List
      • an instance of String
      An InvalidCheckException is thrown if the argument has any other type. 
      
 Check.that(4).is(indexOf(), "Hello world!"); // true
 Check.that(5).is(indexOf(), new File[5]); // true
 Check.that(-1).is(indexOf(), List.of("foo", "bar")); // false
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the array
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • inRange

      public static IntObjRelation<IntPair> inRange()
      Verifies that the argument is greater than or equal to the first integer of the specified IntPair and less than the second.
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • inRangeClosed

      public static IntObjRelation<IntPair> inRangeClosed()
      Verifies that the argument is greater than or equal to the first integer of the specified IntPair and less than or equal to the second.
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • inIntArray

      public static IntObjRelation<int[]> inIntArray()
      Verifies that the argument is present in the specified int array. Equivalent to ArrayMethods::isElementOf.
      Returns:
      A function implementing the test described above

    • illegalState

      public static Function<String,IllegalStateException> illegalState()
      (Not a check) Shortcut for IllegalStateException::new. Can be used in combination with the Check.on() static factory method. For example: Check.on(illegalState(), out.isClosed()).is(no()).
      Returns:
      A Function that takes a String (the exception message) and produces an IllegalStateException

    • indexOutOfBounds

      public static Function<String,IndexOutOfBoundsException> indexOutOfBounds()
      (Not a check) Shortcut for IndexOutOfBoundsException::new.
      Returns:
      A Function that takes a String (the exception message) and produces an IndexOutOfBoundsException

    • io

      public static Function<String,IOException> io()
      (Not a check) Shortcut for IOException::new.
      Returns:
      A Function that takes a String (the exception message) and produces an IOException

    • nullPointer

      public static Function<String,NullPointerException> nullPointer()
      (Not a check) Shortcut for NullPointerException::new. Could be used if you prefer illegal null values to cause a NullPointerException rather than an IllegalArgumentException (as is the default). 
      
 Check.on(nullPointer(), foo, "foo").isNot(NULL());
      Returns:
      A Function that takes a String (the exception message) and produces a NullPointerException

    • asInt

      public static IntPredicate asInt(IntPredicate lambdaOrMethodReference)
      (Not a check) Simply returns the specified IntPredicate. Use when passing a lambda or method reference to the Check.has() and Check.notHas() methods. Because these methods are heavily overloaded, the compiler may not be able to establish whether the lambda is supposed to be a Predicate or IntPredicate (it will complain about an Ambiguous method call). This method clears that up for the compiler.

      NB this method is meant to wrap the test argument of a Check.has() or Check.notHas() method, not the property argument. You only need to wrap one of the arguments to disambiguate the call. It is a matter of taste which one you prefer.

      Parameters:
      lambdaOrMethodReference - A lambda or method reference
      Returns:
      The same IntPredicate

    • asObj

      public static <T> Predicate<T> asObj(Predicate<T> lambdaOrMethodReference)
      (Not a check) Simply returns the specified Predicate. Use when passing a lambda or method reference to the Check.has() and Check.notHas() methods. Because these methods are heavily overloaded, the compiler may not be able to establish whether the lambda is supposed to be a Predicate or IntPredicate (it will complain about an Ambiguous method call). This method clears that up for the compiler.

      NB this method is meant to wrap the test argument of a Check.has() or Check.notHas() method, not the property argument. You only need to wrap one of the arguments to disambiguate the call. It is a matter of taste which one you prefer.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the object being tested
      Parameters:
      lambdaOrMethodReference - A lambda or method reference
      Returns:
      The same Predicate

    • objObj

      public static <T, U> Relation<T,U> objObj(Relation<T,U> lambdaOrMethodReference)
      (Not a check) Simply returns the specified Relation. Use when passing a lambda or method reference to the Check.has() and Check.notHas() methods. Because these methods are heavily overloaded, the compiler may not be able to establish whether the lambda is supposed to be a Relation or one of its sister interfaces (it will complain about an Ambiguous method call). This method clears that up for the compiler.

      NB this method is meant to wrap the test argument of a Check.has() or Check.notHas() method, not the property argument. You only need to wrap one of the arguments to disambiguate the call. It is a matter of taste which one you prefer.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the subject of the Relation
      U - The type of the object of the Relation
      Parameters:
      lambdaOrMethodReference - A lambda or method reference
      Returns:
      The same Relation

    • objInt

Because these methods are heavily overloaded, the compiler may not be able to establish whether the lambda is supposed to be an ObjIntRelation or one of its sister interfaces (it will complain about an Ambiguous method call). This method clears that up for the compiler.

      NB this method is meant to wrap the test argument of a Check.has() or Check.notHas() method, not the property argument. You only need to wrap one of the arguments to disambiguate the call. It is a matter of taste which one you prefer.

      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the subject of the Relation
      Parameters:
      lambdaOrMethodReference - A lambda or method reference
      Returns:
      The same ObjIntRelation

    • objToObj

Because these methods are heavily overloaded, the compiler may not be able to establish whether the lambda is supposed to be an Function or, for example, an IntFunction (it will complain about an Ambiguous method call).
